body:
Hi @mrocklin @TomAugspurger 
Could you please have a look at this?

The test fails due to some `metadata` issue.

I think there is some minor modification that I am missing. Let me know, Thanks!

It seems like in the `_check_dask` function in `dask/dataframe/utils.py`,
`dsk.compute().index` and `dsk._meta.index` differ.

The correct value of the index of the final answer corresponds to `dsk.compute().index`.

Any reason why this could occur?

The functions for `chunk` and `aggregate` only use `pandas` operations inside them. 
I don't think there is a way I can access this `dsk` object inside those.

I haven't looked closely, but this is saying that the metadata for the index was not specified correctly.

There's a mismatch between `df._meta.index.names` and `df.compute().index.names`. We need to make sure that the metadata is correct.

I'm not sure how aca determines the index for meta, or whether it allows you to specify it.
Yes, I figured that out already. But I was wondering how to specify the metadata.

The default assumption for the `metadata` is a `RangeIndex` (by Dask).

However, the final answer can have either `RangeIndex` or `MultiIndex`. This is a `pandas` problem and is unrelated to `dask`. Basically, after applying `nlargest(K)` on a grouped pandas DataFrame, if the result is all of the rows i.e. each group having K rows = the input data itself, we get a `RangeIndex` through pandas.

If the above is not the case, we get a `MultiIndex`.

Now, this seems fine, but while using the `Apply-Concat-Apply` paradigm, it is possible that some blocks of data return the `RangeIndex` while some return the `MultiIndex`.

This doesn't allow us to normally concatenate different blocks.

(unlike in https://blog.dask.org/2019/10/08/df-groupby where the `sr3` block has it's output as all of the rows of input.
Thus, it is consistent with `sr1` and `sr2` in terms of retaining it's index and all `3` of them can be concatenated easily).

Coming back to `nlargest`, since the indexes of different blocks are different. That's why there is a `if-else` block in this PR in the `_nlargest_chunk` function that accounts for this, and converts the `RangeIndex` to a `MultiIndex`, so that different blocks can be concatenated.

What I am essentially trying to say is that my implementation respects the output (as `pandas` wants it) i.e. `RangeIndex` or `MultiIndex` depending on the data and the `K` in `nlargest(K)`.

However, I am not sure how to deal with this `metadata` issue. Hence, I am changing the test simply from `nlargest(1)` to `nlargest(2)`. This way, the result would indeed contain a `RangeIndex` and would thus respect the default settings for metadata as set by dask (i.e. a `RangeIndex` indeed).

Update: I have also sent a new commit that covers / fixes the case when a column being accessed is also present in the grouping keys (eg: `dask_df.groupby(["location", "percent"])["percent"].nlargest(2)`)  i.e. `percent` appears in both these places (playing different roles).

Update: This PR is now ready.
CC: @TomAugspurger @mrocklin

There is a minor case that I just discovered. I shall try to fix it tomorrow or the day after. It's when the `_nlargest_aggregate` function applies `nlargest` on the final aggregated dataframe (the `concat` of each of the chunks) and when it's number of rows = the number of rows of the output (but still less than number of rows of the original input). Although the answer matches, there will be a discrepancy again between `RangeIndex` and `MultiIndex`.
The tests pass for me locally. It seems they only fail for `Windows CI / build (3.6)`. Any tips on how I can reproduce locally?

The raw logs indicate the error as `nlargest() got an unexpected keyword argument 'axis'` which is probably an issue for an older / different version of pandas. I am switching to `keyword arguments` that will hopefully fix this.
Update: The total number of tests are now 36. All of them pass locally for me. More corner cases have been fixed with the latest commit.

I have gone over 540 possible combinations of what we can pass as `fields` for groupby and the `name` for which we seek `nlargest` values. All of them pass except the case when both the field and the name are the same.

For eg: `dask_df.groupby(["percent"])["percent"].nlargest(n=n, keep=keep).compute()`
Update: This should be ready to merge!

cc @dask/maintenance 
@madhur-tandon : note that you have failures on CI

Hi @martindurant Yup, but they are unrelated to this PR.
It probably occurs due to an older / different version of pandas for `Python 3.6`.

The error is `nlargest() got an unexpected keyword argument 'axis'`.

Perhaps the older version of pandas used to have this argument. But I am not able to find the relevant old docs for it.
I am certain that upgrading pandas on the `Windows CI / build (3.6)` machine should fix it.
It would be better to add an xfail for the specific condition, with an explanation - otherwise all other test runs would fail after merging this
Alternatively, one could remove this config since `pandas is dropping support for Python 3.6` and `dask` depends on `pandas`. (https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/35214)
In a separate discussion, we will drop py36 support sometime soon, but I would xfail this anyway for now (*only* for py36)
Done, Hopefully everything should pass now 👍
Hi @madhur-tandon! Thank you for your patience on this PR. I realize it's been a while, would you still be interested in picking this back up again?
Can one of the admins verify this patch?
